BasicIO

Class ASCIIDisplayer

  • java.lang.Object
    • BasicIO.ASCIIDisplayer

  • public class ASCIIDisplayer
extends java.lang.Object
    ASCIIDisplayer is used as a quick way to produce text output to the screen. It mimics writting to a file using ASCIIOutputFile, however instead of the data going to a text file, the data is displayed in a text area on a form on the screen.
    Version:
    1.0 July 2008
    Author:
    Andrew Cheesman

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      ASCIIDisplayer()
      Constructs an ASCIIDisplayer as a form on the screen with a text area to which text may be written.
      ASCIIDisplayer(int nRow, int nCol)
      Constructs an ASCIIDisplayer as a form on the screen with a text area of specified number of rows and columns, to which text may be written.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods Deprecated Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void close()
      Closes the ASCIIDisplayer and frees resources when the user presses Close.
      void hide()
      Makes the ASCIIDisplayer invisible, so that it can not be seen on the desktop.
      void newLine()
      Writes a newline character so that the next write starts at the beginning of the next line.

      Changes the text of the label on the text area of the ASCIIDisplayer.
      void show()
      Makes the ASCIIDisplayer visible, so that it can be seen on the desktop.
      void waitForUser()
      Waits for the user to finish using the ASCIIDisplayer and press OK.

      Writes a boolean to the displayer.

        public void writeEOL()
        Deprecated. Use newLine() instead.
        Writes a newline character so that the next write starts at the beginning of the next line.

      • writeObject

        public void writeObject(java.lang.Object o)
        Writes the String representation of an Object to the displayer.
        Parameters:
        o - the object to be written.

      • newLine

        public void newLine()
        Writes a newline character so that the next write starts at the beginning of the next line.

      • writeByte

        public void writeByte(byte b,
                      int length)
        Writes a byte to the displayer. The data output will take up a number of characters specified by by the length provided. If the output would have been shorter spaces will be added. If the output would have been longer, then it will be truncated.
        Parameters:
        b - a byte to be displayed on the displayer
        length - the number of characters that the output will be.

      • writeDouble

        public void writeDouble(double d,
                        int length,
                        int decimals)
        Writes a double to the displayer. The data output will take up a number of characters specified by by the length provided. If the output would have been shorter spaces will be added. If the output would have been longer, then it will be truncated. The paramter decimals will determine how many decimal places will be displayed.
        Parameters:
        d - a double to be displayed on the displayer
        length - the number of characters that will be outputed.
        decimals - the number of decimal characters that will be outputted.

      • writeFloat

        public void writeFloat(float f,
                       int length,
                       int decimals)
        Writes a float to the displayer. The data output will take up a number of characters specified by by the length provided. If the output would have been shorter spaces will be added. If the output would have been longer, then it will be truncated. The paramter decimals will determine how many decimal characters will be displayed.
        Parameters:
        f - a float to be displayed on the displayer
        length - the number of characters that will be outputed.
        decimals - the number of decimal characters that will be outputted.

      • writeInt

        public void writeInt(int i,
                     int length)
        Writes an int to the displayer. The data output will take up a number of characters specified by by the length provided. If the output would have been shorter spaces will be added. If the output would have been longer, then it will be truncated.
        Parameters:
        i - an int to be displayed on the displayer
        length - the number of characters that the output will be.

      • writeShort

        public void writeShort(short s,
                       int length)
        Writes a short to the displayer. The data output will take up a number of characters specified by by the length provided. If the output would have been shorter spaces will be added. If the output would have been longer, then it will be truncated.
        Parameters:
        s - a short to be displayed on the displayer
        length - the number of characters that the output will be.

      • writeLong

        public void writeLong(long l,
                      int length)
        Writes a long to the displayer. The data output will take up a number of characters specified by by the length provided. If the output would have been shorter spaces will be added. If the output would have been longer, then it will be truncated.
        Parameters:
        l - a long to be displayed on the displayer
        length - the number of characters that the output will be.

      • waitForUser

        public void waitForUser()
        Waits for the user to finish using the ASCIIDisplayer and press OK.

      • show

        public void show()
        Makes the ASCIIDisplayer visible, so that it can be seen on the desktop.

      • hide

        public void hide()
        Makes the ASCIIDisplayer invisible, so that it can not be seen on the desktop.

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the ASCIIDisplayer and frees resources when the user presses Close. The ASCIIDisplayer should not be used thereafter.
